item.title: Biden blasts 'radical' Roe v. Wade draft, warns other rights at risk
item.description: U.S. President Joe Biden on Tuesday blasted a 'radical' Supreme Court draft opinion that would throw out the landmark Roe v. Wade abortion rights ruling that has stood for a half century. The court cautioned no final decision had been made, but Biden warned other privacy rights including same-sex marriage and birth control are at risk if the justices follow through.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.enclosure: U.S. President Joe Biden before boarding Air Force One for a trip to Alabama, on May 3, 2022. (Evan Vucci / AP)

item.title: Body found in barrel as Nevada's Lake Mead water level drops
item.description: The body found inside a barrel in the newly exposed bottom of Lake Mead after the lake's level was depleted amid drought is that a man who was shot, police said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.enclosure: The top of Lake Mead drinking water Intake No. 1 above the surface level of the Colorado River reservoir behind Hoover Dam, on April 25, 2022. (Southern Nevada Water Authority via AP)

item.title: Ivanka Trump talked to Jan. 6 committee about what was happening inside White House that day: panel chairman
item.description: The Trump family's co-operation with the House select committee investigating the January 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol -- and Ivanka Trump's appearance in particular -- has proven useful in confirming other key testimony about the state of play inside the White House as well as then-President Donald Trump's state of mind that day.
item.dc:creator: CNN
item.enclosure: Ivanka Trump comes onto stage as then-U.S. President Donald Trump speaks at a campaign rally in support of Senate candidates Sen. Kelly Loeffler, R-Ga., and David Perdue in Dalton, Ga., Jan. 4, 2021. (AP Photo/Brynn Anderson, File)

item.title: 'What is going on in Shanghai': Horror as elderly man taken to morgue in body bag -- while still alive
item.description: An elderly Shanghai resident was mistakenly declared dead and taken to a morgue in a body bag, in the latest sign of dysfunction in the COVID-stricken city where millions of people remain under government-enforced lockdown.
item.dc:creator: CNN
item.enclosure: Shanghai, China is seen in this May 3, 2022 photo. (Source: Bloomberg / Getty Images via CNN)

item.title: U.S. Senate vows vote on abortion, but not filibuster changes
item.description: Furious Senate Democrats vowed Tuesday to vote on legislation to protect abortion access for millions of Americans, but without broader support from Republicans, Congress is essentially powerless to prevent the unraveling of the landmark Roe v. Wade ruling.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.enclosure: Abortion rights advocates and anti-abortion protesters demonstrate in front of the U.S. Supreme Court, on Dec. 1, 2021. (Andrew Harnik / AP)

item.title: 'Very disturbing': Gloria Allred worries overturning Roe v. Wade could roll back other rights
item.description: A high-profile women's rights lawyer worries that if the U.S. Supreme Court overturns the case that legalized abortion in the U.S., it would be the first step in eroding other hard-won rights, such as same-sex or interracial marriage.
item.dc:creator: Tom Yun
item.enclosure: Attorney Gloria Allred speaks to the media on the guilty verdict of R. Kelly at the Brooklyn Federal Courthouse, Monday, Sept. 27, 2021, in New York. (AP Photo/Brittainy Newman)

item.title: Oklahoma governor signs Texas-style ban on most abortions
item.description: Oklahoma's Republican Gov. Kevin Stitt signed a Texas-style abortion ban on Tuesday that prohibits abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy, part of a nationwide push in GOP-led states hopeful that the conservative U.S. Supreme Court will uphold new restrictions.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.enclosure: Oklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt speaks at a signing ceremony to sign into law a bill, Tuesday, April 12, 2022, in Oklahoma City. (AP Photo/Sue Ogrocki, File)

item.title: Baseball signed by Zelenskyy to be sold for Ukraine relief
item.description: The official Rawlings Major League baseball signed by Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy is being sold by Randy Kaplan, a renowned collector of balls signed by world leaders, with a portion of the proceeds going to war relief efforts in Ukraine, auctioneer RR Auction of Boston said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.enclosure: This image provided by RR Auction shows a baseball signed by Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. (RR Auction via AP)

item.title: Norman Mineta, U.S. transportation secretary in 9/11 era, dies
item.description: Norman Mineta, who broke racial barriers for Asian Americans serving in high-profile government posts and ordered commercial flights grounded after the 9/11 terror attacks as the nation's federal transportation secretary, died Tuesday. He was 90.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.enclosure: Transportation Secretary Norman Mineta listens to questions during a news conference at O'Hare International Airport, Monday, Nov. 21, 2005, in Chicago. (AP Photo/Nam Y. Huh, File)

item.title: NXIVM founder alleges FBI tampered with key evidence in his case, asks conviction be vacated
item.description: An attorney for NXIVM founder Keith Raniere on Tuesday asked for his conviction to be vacated, alleging in a court filing the FBI tampered with key evidence in the case against him and gave false testimony in his 2019 trial.
item.dc:creator: CNN
item.enclosure: FILE - In this June 18, 2019 file courtroom artist's sketch, defendant Keith Raniere, centre, sits with attorneys Paul DerOhannesian, left, and Marc Agnifilo during closing arguments at Brooklyn federal court in New York. (Elizabeth Williams via AP, File)
